instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Smoking Joe Frazier <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> came in stone dead. No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Resistance to ground was near 0. So I injected 4.0V into G3H and see that <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> go hot. Changed it and only got 0.5V on G3H. Found F7140 was no good. Changed it and when I plugged in DC power <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> started to smoke. I see <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> does go to ground, so it is shorting to ground. When it was removed I did a continuity check on the pins with ground and none of them beeped. Like standing in a crossroad and saying DF?!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Smoking Joe Frazier <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: I bet <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> got PPBUS on it so this board will be toasted. Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> and check for a short on L7560. If shorted this board can go in the trash.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Smoking Joe Frazier <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: No short there or on any pins on <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>. I did change <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> & ISL. And <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> smokes again. (Parts came from a donor/s)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Smoking Joe Frazier <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: So I changed <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> & <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> and is working.  I followed your advice in someone else's question. Thank you.
